title: What Is a Postpartum Hemorrhage?
author: WebMD Editorial Contributor

content: A postpartum hemorrhage, also known as PPH, is a serious but rare condition that causes women to bleed uncontrollably after giving birth. This typically happens within 1 day of giving birth but can occur up to 12 weeks after having a baby.

Although it's normal to lose blood during childbirth, a postpartum hemorrhage is much more serious. Due to significant blood loss, postpartum hemorrhage can cause a drop in your blood pressure. Your organs may not get enough blood flow which can cause you to go into shock and possibly die.

sections.heading: How Does Postpartum Hemorrhage Happen?
content: When you’re pregnant, your body develops a placenta — an organ that develops inside your uterus. It is a structure for your baby that provides them with the oxygen and nutrients they need to grow. It also removes waste products from your baby’s food. The placenta attaches to the wall of your uterus, and your baby's umbilical cord comes out from it.

After childbirth, the uterus typically contracts to push out the placenta. These contractions can help put pressure on the bleeding vessels near where the placenta is typically attached inside your uterus. If the contractions during childbirth aren’t strong enough, the vessels bleed more. Bleeding can also happen if small pieces of the placenta don’t leave the body and stay attached.

content: If the placenta isn’t delivered within 30 minutes after childbirth, it’s known as a retained placenta. If it or parts of it are still attached to the uterine wall, it can cause severe infection or life-threatening blood loss. Signs of placental problems include:

sections.heading: Symptoms of Postpartum Hemorrhage
content: Each woman is unique and may experience postpartum hemorrhage differently. These are the most common symptoms:
bullets: Uncontrolled bleeding
Decreased blood pressure
Increased heart rate
Decreased red blood cell count
Swelling and pain in the vaginal area

sections.heading: Cause of Postpartum Hemorrhage
content: Some women are more at risk for postpartum hemorrhage than others. Some conditions that increase your risk include:
Postpartum hemorrhage may also be caused by:
bullets: Placental abruption: the placenta’s early detachment from the uterus
Placenta previa: placenta covers or is near the cervical opening
Overstretched uterus: excessive enlargement of the uterus due to a large baby or too much amniotic fluid
Multiple pregnancies: more than one placenta and excessive stretching of the uterus
Gestational hypertension or preeclampsia: high blood pressure due to pregnancy
Having multiple previous births
Labor that lasts longer than average
Infection
Obesity
Medications to induce labor
Medications to stop contractions (for preterm labor)
The use of vacuum-assisted delivery or forceps
General anesthesia
Tear in cervix or tissue in the vagina
Tear in a blood vessel of the uterus
Bleeding into a hidden tissue area (usually the vulva or vagina)
Blood clot disorders
Placenta problems

sections.heading: How is Postpartum Hemorrhage Diagnosed?
content: Your doctor can help diagnose postpartum hemorrhages. After reviewing your health history, they will do a variety of tests including:
bullets: An evaluation of how much blood was lost
Measuring blood pressure and pulse
Measuring red blood cell count
Looking for potential blood clots

sections.heading: How is Postpartum Hemorrhage Treated?
content: Your doctor can help determine which treatment options will work best for you. They’ll evaluate:
The goal of treatment is to stop you from bleeding as quickly as possible. Treatment for PPH may include:
bullets: Your health history, overall health, and pregnancy
Severity of the postpartum hemorrhage condition
Your tolerance for different medications and treatments
Your personal preference
Medication
Massaging the uterus to start contractions
Removal of any placenta pieces still in the uterus
Examination of the uterus and pelvic tissue
Inserting a Foley catheter or a uterine balloon tamponade to compress bleeding in the uterus
Packing the uterus with sterile materials and sponges
Use a vacuum device inside the uterus to stimulate contractions to control the bleeding
Tying off bleeding blood vessels
Surgery where the abdomen is cut open to find the source of the bleeding
Surgical removal of the uterus ( hysterectomy ) , which may be considered as a last resort

content: Replacing lost fluids and blood is important in treating postpartum hemorrhage. Intravenous (IV) fluids, as well as blood and blood products, can be given rapidly to prevent shock. The mother may also receive oxygen by mask.
Postpartum hemorrhage can be quite serious. However, quickly detecting and treating the cause of bleeding can often lead to a full recovery.
